body: PG number?

List of refactoring and code improvements that should be applied to the `routemgmt` package:

1. [ ] refactor arg validation so that it validates all args at once and reports one error message (rather than sequential validation)
1. [ ] refactor common db operation into reusable module (this will remove nearly 1000 lines of clone and own code in favor of a more manageable module that may be shared across the package actions)
1. [ ] remove all uses of `whisk.` and use promises instead since the `whisk` object is deprecated 
1. [ ]  remove unnecessary logging of arguments

OK to merge this pr so that it will work with the meta-API handler since much of this package is already in. The routemgmt package will require further cleanup and refactoring as noted here https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1511#issuecomment-266214580. Further consideration should be given to https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1629.

With the roll out of a stricter 1-1 mapping from key to namespace, an alternate way to evolve the API is to drop the `namespace` entirely from the URI (since the value will always be unambiguous and the `_` place holder becomes canonical).

So rather than always specifying resources with `/namespaces/_/{actions, triggers, rules, activations, packages}/name` it becomes more convenient, elegant and uniform to drop the `/namespaces/_` segment and treat the entire path following one of the collection qualifiers as the fully qualified name (where one segment implies resource in default namespace and package, two segments implies resource in default namespace with named package and entity) and three segments implies a fully qualified name with namespace, package and entity names.

This makes it potentially nicer to also filter activations in a namespace, package or by action:
`/activations/` lists all activation in the namespace, `/activations/package-name` for activations filtered by package, and `/activations/package-name/entity-name` for activations of an entity in a package. And of course `/activations/namespace-name/package-name` and  `/activations/namespace-name/package-name/action-name` for activation in some other namespace and package assuming entitled subject.

(Alternatively, activations could be come their own resources under the actions collection `actions/action-name/activations` e.g.)

Related to #1635.

Any thoughts from frequent JS users @jthomas @csantanapr @jasonpet ?
on making them consistent. Putting rejected promises messages into `error` is the way to go IMO.
What should the behavior be when a promise is rejected with a json object as opposed to a string?

Hi @csantanapr I must have misread it, I cannot find oldDoc in the correct context either.

Having that Filter function available would help a whole lot.

Currently, the container promotes any rejected value `V` to `{ error: V }`, since having an `error` field in an activation is the signal for, well, errors.

So `Promise.reject("oh no")` turns into `{ error: "oh no" }`, `Promise.reject({ reason: "panic" })` turns into `{ error: { reason: "panic" }}` etc.

There is the additional catch that if `V` is `undefined` (or in general false-y), it is replaced by `{}`. This is to address #1562, where the issue was that `{ error: undefined }` is the same as `{}`, which doesn't communicate that there was an error.

One proposal is that if `V` is somehow not JSON-serializable, we should fall back to what we do for exceptions, i.e. returning ```{ error: `An error has occured: $V` } ```. This would be consistent.

Now, an additional option is to treat instances of `Error` as special cases, and just do `{ error: V.message }` (additionally logging the stack trace), both for exceptions and rejected promises.
@rabbah, anything else on this one?
LGTM.  One question, is the precise text of the timed out case part of the contract?
Yes - admittedly I was lazy this time and didn't move this to the `Messages` singleton where I've incrementally accumulated the error responses. At your insistence, I'll do that.

Either that or inline a comment in the test case so that if there is a discrepancy (we'll eventually change wording or internationalize), whoever gets the bug will have a clue.

I actually prefer the last option: turn `Promise.reject(new Error('oh no')` into `{ "error": "oh no" }` + logging of stack trace. The addition of `An error has occured: `, IMO, is unnecessary at best and confusing at worst.

Yes, we should remove the swift container when its convenient.

Here is what I have found/done so far:

The Ubuntu 1404 AMI provided by Amazon is quite different from the Vagrant Box used by OpenWhisk.
I tried 'Native Ubuntu' installation on AWS for quite a while but I just couldn't get the installation to finish. It was failing in the last couple of ansible operations.

I found a (brute force) solution of creating an AWS  AMI from the exact Vagrant box used by OpenWhisk and using that as a starting point. I listed out all the Shell commands run by the Vagrant provisioning and ran them manually on this instance. And it works!

So it is a matter of pre-requisites.
